general.headline: Corporate & Commercial Practice Group Leader, National Head of Intellectual Property and Partner at Sparke Helmore
general.description:
Summary
I am a solicitor and a Trade Marks Attorney with more than 20 years’ experience advising leading national and global organisations on all aspects of brand protection, intellectual property litigation and the commercialisation of intellectual property. I currently head the Intellectual Property team as well as oversee Sparke Helmore Lawyers’ Corporate & Commercial practice.

The clients I work with represent a diverse range of industries, including engineering, chemicals, FMCG, creative arts, information technology, hospitality and leisure. My team and I manage an international trade marks portfolio of over 4,000 marks and advise on brand protection, trade mark registrability and enforcement, opposition and non-use prosecution proceedings before the Trade Marks Office. We also represent clients in Federal Court brand protection litigation, advertising and marketing collateral clearance, and trade promotions.

I’m incredibly proud of my team’s achievements and the accolades we have received. We have been recognised for four consecutive years as a leading trade mark practice in the World Trade Mark Review’s WTR 1000. We were ranked in the 2017 edition of Legal 500 and shortlisted for the Intellectual Property Team of the Year category at the 2016 Lawyers Weekly Australian Law Awards. We were also awarded NSW Patent Litigator of the Year at Acquisition International's 2016 Intellectual Property Awards and in 2017 they named us Best Law Firm in NSW. 

I was incredibly humbled to be awarded Intellectual Property Partner of the Year at Lawyers Weekly’s Partner of the Year Awards and also Partner of the Year at their Women in Law Awards in 2016.

jobs.jobTitle: Partner & National Head of Intellectual Property
jobs.description:
I specialise in brand protection, IP litigation and IP commercialisation. I advise on the registrability of trade marks and designs, as well as on brand protection, technology licensing, trade promotions, advertising clearance, ICANN clearing house services and IP commercialisation generally. I also manage a number of national and international trade mark portfolios, and act in trade mark opposition and non-use proceedings before the Trade Marks Office. 

In 2016, I took on the role of Corporate & Commercial Practice Group Leader, which means I am responsible for the strategic direction, financial performance and operation of the Group. In this capacity, I also sit on the firm’s Executive Committee—a consultative and advisory forum that supports high level decision-making across the firm.

general.headline: Special Counsel | Sparke Helmore Lawyers | Melbourne | Employment and WHS
general.description:
Sam works in the Workplace group at Sparke Helmore Lawyers in Melbourne. 

Sam has extensive experience advising clients on work health and safety (WHS) matters, including advising clients in the aftermath of serious workplace incidents, in their dealings with WHS regulators, by providing them with strategic WHS advice and by acting in defence of numerous WHS prosecutions in the Victorian, New South Wales and Comcare jurisdictions. 

Sam's employment experience spans both litigious and advisory work, and includes acting in a number of recent Federal Court matters for the Australian Building and Construction Commissioner. 

In addition to his litigation practice, Sam provides practical and commercial advice to his clients on both employment and WHS. His expertise across both fields enables him to advise clients in a way that recognises the close relationship between these areas by identifying issues early, thus ensuring his clients can address issues proactively.

Sam was listed as a Rising Star for both Employment and WHS by Doyles Guide in 2018. 

He has a Bachelor of Commerce and Bachelor of Laws (First Class Honours) from the University of Tasmania, and a Masters of Laws from the University of Melbourne.

Before joining Sparke Helmore in April 2015, Sam gained experience in the employment and WHS groups of K&L Gates and Freehills (now Herbert Smith Freehills), as well as an 8 month rotation in the commercial litigation group at Freehills. Since commencing his practice in WHS at Freehills in 2009, Sam has worked alongside industry leading WHS lawyer, Penny Stevens.

Sam has a passion for pro-bono and community work, volunteering each week at the St Kilda Legal Service providing employment and other advice to their clients and is also a former member of the Victorian Equal Opportunity and Human Rights Commission's Disability Discrimination Reference Group [2014 to 2016].

jobs.description:
Special Counsel within Sparke Helmore's Workplace group in Melbourne, focusing on employment and health and safety litigation, including:

• Acting for companies in various sectors to defend alleged breaches of the general protections (adverse action) provisions of the Fair Work Act 2009 in the Federal Court of Australia and Federal Circuit Court of Australia. 
• Acting for employers defending unfair dismissal applications in the Fair Work Commission, including successfully negotiating commercial settlements in the vast majority of matters.
• Acting for companies following serious workplace incidents, including attending site immediately following the incident, liaising with the relevant WHS regulator and responding to statutory requests.
• Representing companies prosecuted under state WHS legislation, including successfully defending a number of those companies. 
• Acting in a number of matters involving the Commonwealth WHS Regulator, Comcare, including acting for a major national construction company in the first criminal prosecutions by Comcare under WHS legislation and acting in a number of the criminal prosecutions commenced by Comcare since.

In addition to litigation, regularly engaged to provide practical, commercial and proactive advice on employment and WHS, including training from the shop floor to the Boardroom.

Senior Associate within Sparke Helmore's Workplace group, focusing on employment
      
      and health and safety litigation.

Senior Associate within the K&L Gates (formerly Middletons) Labor Employment and Workplace Safety group. Some significant matters included:

•  Acting for the Australian Football League in proceedings in the Fair Work Commission regarding an enterprise bargaining dispute.
•  Acting for a publicly listed mining company in proceedings in the Federal Court of Australia involving allegations of breaches of the general protections provisions of the Fair Work Act 2009 by a former CEO.
• Acting in various matters involving Comcare, including acting for the Australian arm of a multi-national corporation in its successful defence of civil penalty proceedings in the Federal Court of Australia and acting for a national transport company in civil penalty proceedings in the Federal Court of Australia
•  Representing numerous companies prosecuted under state WHS legislation, including successfully defending a number of those companies. 
•  Acting for a national retailer in its successful appeal of statutory notices issued by WorkSafe Victoria that would have had significant financial implications for the retailer’s national operations had they not been overturned.
•  Acting for a Fortune 500 company on the WHS and employment aspects of a €1.6B multi entity global acquisition strategy.

Lawyer within the K&L Gates (formerly Middletons) Labor, Employment and Workplace
      
      Safety group.

Graduate solicitor and solicitor within the Freehills Employee Relations and Commercial Litigation groups, including gaining extensive experience on complex IR, ER and WHS matters and having exposure to significant commercial litigation matters including acting in the 2009 Bushfires Royal Commission, the Centro Shareholders class action and a commercial arbitration in relation to the Mechanical and Electrical subcontract for the EastLink road and tunnel infrastructure project.
Seasonal Clerkship within the Freehills Employee Relations group
Seasonal Clerkship within the Corrs Chambers Westgarth Workplace Relations group
Human Resource Management Internship

general.headline: Assisting Business Leaders & Entrepreneurs to engineer business success and create the life they desire and deserve
general.description:
At 21, with less than $1000, I made a radical life-changing decision: to be happy. Instead of allowing a difficult upbringing to define me and keep me down, I instead launched my first business and I have continued to climb higher ever since. 

As a transformational teacher, learning junkie, spiritual being and adventure I have built an international reputation as a hard-charging, rule-breaking, high performance entrepreneur, speaker, and transformational coach. As a certified trainer and facilitator for Mindvalley and Entrepreneur Resorts I am able to combine world class content and methodologies with 2 decades of experience building businesses.

Among other accolades, I have been honoured as one of StartUp Daily's Top 50 Women Entrepreneurs Under 40, received two Bronze International Stevie Awards for Women in Business, and my Search Firm, Velocity Consulting, was the very first business to receive investment from The Entourage Growth Fund.   

The difficult upbringing I escaped from, it turned out, was the very thing that allowed me to help others at an even higher level. Possessing a knack for "reverse engineering" all aspects of their life, they'd quickly gain clarity on why they were unhappy, but also what needed to change (and how) in order to design a business and a life they truly love. 

I have noticed that, again and again, my most financially successful clients were also surprisingly unhappy. They made all the right moves, ticked all the right boxes, but remained fundamentally unfulfilled. So last year I decided it was time to make a difference and help solve this issue by founding Life: Engineered, which helps the founders of fast growth start up businesses reverse engineer all aspects of their life to ensure that they are not only building a successful business that they love but also living a life aligned with their souls true desires.

jobs.description:
Did you know that 67% of a buyers journey is done digitally. 
74% of B2B + 84% of C level use social media (mainly LinkedIn) to make a purchasing decision and consumes at LEAST 5 pieces of someone’s content before deciding to buy.

In this 6 week Online Course & Group Mentoring Program you will:
•Learn how Jade went from 10,000 t0 20,000 genuine connections (and growing at over 100 requests per day) and from maximum 3,000 views to over 50,000 organic views per post in just a few months!
•Understand why it is imperative you have a strong personal brand and how social proofing affects your ability to close sales & attract talent
•Gain a blueprint on how to create a LinkedIn profile that has maximum impact and credibility
•Build your network and learn how to leverage it across multiple platforms and marketing campaigns
•Discover how to gain testimonials that will position you as an employer and/or supplier of choice
•Learn specific techniques on how to increase your profile views, search appearances and post views and engagement
•Take action so that you can start actively attracting business TO you
•Develop an outreach campaign to reach out directly to customers, partners and talent
•Start creating content that engages your target market and converts
AND
• Gain access to Jade’s LinkedIn Sacred Circle. 
The Sacred Circle is ONLY for those 100% committed to growing their network, gaining organic traffic and harnessing the power of social selling. The Sacred circle is we band together to hack LinkedIn’s algorithms and gain organic reach for our posts.


The Next Kick Off is Early October

Also offering Business and First Class programs where Jade will personally hold your hand to ensure success.

jobs.jobTitle: Be Extraordinary | Mindvalley's Flagship 1 day Seminar
jobs.description:
MELBOURNE OCTOBER 7th | SYDNEY NOVEMBER 4th

Be Extraordinary is Mindvalley's 1-day flagship seminar designed by Vishen himself, based on the ideas developed from the last 15 years of Mindvalley and shared in the hit book “The Code of the Extraordinary Mind”. 

It integrates Vishen's powerful 6-Phase meditation, advanced goal setting and key philosophies from our top teachers to give you a powerful framework to bend reality and live an extraordinary life. 

You will go through liberating radical forgiveness exercises and empowering gratitude and compassion meditation that will boost your happiness here and now. On the top of that - you will create a vision for the future and learn how to manifest it in your life. 

You can find out more about this seminar here: https://www.mindvalley.com/be/australia/melbourne & https://www.mindvalley.com/be/australia/sydney

The training will be delivered by our Mindvalley Master Certified Trainers: Jade Green and Amrit Sandhu and hosted by Kae Bajwa

jobs.jobTitle: Life Engineer | Business Consultant | Speaker | Entrepreneur | Surfer | Learning Junkie
jobs.description:
Life: Engineered helps the founders of fast growth start up businesses reverse engineer all aspects of their life to ensure that they are not only building a successful business that they love but also living the life of their dreams.

Often the founders (the ones in our target market) are feeling pain from working to many hours and wearing to many hats and complain about the inability to attract world class quality talent and that it takes to long to find someone to fill the role, takes the manager to much time 'out' of the business doing the recruitment and on-boarding not to mention the cost to the business of both recruiting fees and hiring the wrong person (time, money, lack of sales).
Their personal life is suffering from being enslaved to the business and living the “hustle is the new black” lifestyle. They know that want balance but don’t know how to achieve it.

So on most occasions Life: Engineered will start with solving the Human Capital issues (with our Attract | Retain | Maximise program) and then introduce the other solutions as the burden of time becomes lighter.

The "other" solutions range from Mindvalley seminars and quests, 1:1 coaching / Group coaching around business and "My Life Engineered" (blueprint for creating the life that your spirit truely wants to experience in this lifetime), group coaching and some co-created specialty courses on things like Health and Wellness, Relationships and Mindfulness etc.

JOIN THE WAIT LIST FOR OUR NEXT WORKATION
A | R | M is a revolutionary new system that helps the founders of fast growth start-ups ATTRACT the best possible talent, fast & profitably, RETAIN them in the business, with effective onboard and training, minimising staff turnover and MAXIMISE their potential by creating company cultures that result in higher performance, increased profitability and happier humans.

In our Work Well For Wealth sessions we:
Form the steps you need to take to stop over captialising in your business so that you can grow with an impact to the market and profit to the business at the very same time
Re-engage your business and personal self, the best use of your skills, your personal traits and ideation abilities, and incorporate them to influence your ability to be able to retain the right type of staff to the business
Create your Human Capital Blueprint, plan and execute the exact success strategies your business needs to be able to grow leveraging your team
Unlock your business three key force questions Why You, Why Now, Why Them, that lead to interactive discussions with the best choice candidates for the role you need to fill
Build your limitless employer brand, so you can attract the top talent, even steal them away from your competitors
Procure and prime process management, start new staff to the business effortlessly, without that lag in downtime that costs you money
Develop your own version of the four-step system that allows for long term staff retention. 
Create your Lead From The Front Legion, incorporating this into the business enables your staff to develop themselves and their skills from the first day that begin working for you!
Uncover your ‘Freedom Number’ for your business.
Re-establish what success really looks like for you, beyond societies conventions, through to true abundance and psychic consciousness

VISION 
Enable people to be the best version of themselves.

MISSION
To be the worlds largest enabler of humans who are happy at work

VALUES
Stand Out
We strive to be the inspiration for others to want to grow into their best self. Our stand out energy, words and actions make us unforgettable and give others a glimpse into their potential.

Be Transparent
We have the necessary conversations with everybody in the world of Velocity. With our clients this comes to life through transparent conversations that ensure they only employ humans who are truly aligned with their unique culture. With our talent this comes to life through honest feedback that enables them to grow into the best version of themselves. 

Be Consistent
We are obsessively consistent in our energy, our performance and our interactions. Regardless of who you deal with at Velocity, you will be met with the same authentic DNA.

On Point
We don’t corner cut. We are here to do our life’s best work at all times. Our world-class standard flows through everything we do from our guiding principles through to the tiniest detail.

Radiate Energy
We believe in being happy at work. People that contribute the most and who do their best work are those who are fulfilled and aligned. We believe that happiness and performance come hand in hand therefore everyone we touch feels infused with the Velocity energy.

Have Pride
It’s important that we’re proud of ourselves, the work we do and the lives we change. And we pride ourselves on doing this in a way which truly aligns with the Velocity values. In an industry that places little value on values, our commitment to our own integrity means we shine bright.

Step Up
The worlds best performers, the 1%ers, didn't get there by resting on their laurels, they grab life by the horns and hold themselves accountable for their own growth, development and performance. At Velocity we all believe in being a 1%er!

jobs.jobTitle: National Operations Manager & NSW State Manager
jobs.description:
SALES RECRUITMENT

I joined bta in 2009 as the National Operations Manager and in January 2010 I also took on the NSW State Manager responsibilities. 

I brought to bta over 5 years sales recruitment experience gained in both NSW and VIC with a direct competitor. Starting as a consultant in 2004 and working my way up to General Manager, my fee generation and team leading abilities paved the way to my success in starting up new interstate offices and being extremely influential in significant year on year growth for my previous company.

I was responsible for implementing innovative changes nationally and for the expansion of the Sydney business. Based out of the Sydney office I had national responsibilities across a combination of sales management and operational duties with a key focus on the training and development of staff to ensure that the benchmark for sales recruitment in Australia is raised to a higher level.

SALES RECRUITMENT

jobs.jobTitle: NSW Law Society Accredited Specialist in Family Law
jobs.description:
I completed my law degree at the University of Newcastle in 2006, and also completed a Bachelor of Science (Forensic) in 2004.  After university, I completed my practical legal training at the College of Law in Sydney, where I obtained a Diploma of Legal Practice.  

Whilst I now focus exclusively on family law matters, I have had experience in a number of different areas of law including conveyancing, wills and estates, and local court criminal and traffic matters.  Family law has always been my primary interest area, and in 2015 I achieved my goal of becoming an Accredited Specialist in this area.  

In 2013 I obtained a Graduate Certificate in Applied Law (Family Law) through the College of Law.

I am a past secretary and current committee member of the Hunter Valley Family Law Practitioners Association.  I am a member of the Family Law Section of the Law Council of Australia, the Newcastle Law Society, and the Law Society of New South Wales.  

I have a keen interest in business matters, and I have previously spent multiple years as a director of the Hunter Young Professionals Network (formerly Newcastle and Hunter Junior Chamber).

I'm admitted to the Supreme Court of New South Wales, and entered on the High Court register of practitioners, and I am entitled to appear in all federal courts.

general.headline: Managing Director - Sydney Workplace Relations at Australian Business Lawyers & Advisors
general.description:
Luis oversees ABLA's Sydney Workplace Relations practice and has over a decade’s experience practicing as a specialist employment and industrial relations lawyer. 
 
Luis’ advocacy experience in State and Federal Courts and Tribunals is extensive. In addition to achieving successful outcomes for clients as an advocate in numerous unfair dismissal and industrial dispute arbitrations, Luis acted as one of the lead employer advocates in the 2014/2015 Fair Work Commission Annual Leave Test Case as well as the highly publicised 2016/2017 Penalty Rates Test Case. Following heavily contested hearings in both proceedings, Luis ultimately succeeded in securing a raft of amendments to modern awards in respect of both annual leave and weekend penalty rates. 
 
Luis is the trusted advisor for a number of organisations when it comes to large scale industrial bargaining. In the public sector, he has been the principal advisor on department-wide enterprise agreement negotiations, covering tens of thousands of public sector employees. In the private sector, Luis has advised on enterprise bargaining for the transport, education, aviation, manufacturing, pharmaceutical and food and beverage industries. This experience has also extended to obtaining orders preventing unlawful industrial action and successfully resisting good faith bargaining claims and scope order applications filed by union parties.

Luis has conducted numerous investigations for clients in relation to internal employment disputes and bullying and harassment matters and continues to be a lead litigator in the developing General Protections and bullying jurisdictions.

In addition to working in private practice, Luis has been seconded to the Australian Federal Police and the Fair Work Ombudsman, working on a variety of employment related litigation and prosecutions and is a member of the Law Society of NSW’s Employment Law Committee.

general.description:
With a background in Federal and State politics and over 5 years of experience in employment law practice, I am particularly interested in the political and legislative framework of workplace law in Australia. It is an area of the law that is highly relevant, challenging and subject to amendment as Governments change.

I enjoy assisting businesses, in a practical way, to manage their workplace obligations and risks across their workforce, and to solve the many employee issues that can arise from the recruitment stage, through to termination and everything in between. In particular, my goal is to assist clients to work through any problems before they escalate, in order to avoid litigation.

In assisting clients, I aim to be approachable, pragmatic, responsive and strategic.

I can be contacted on 02 9458 7022.

general.headline: Workplace & Safety Lawyer
general.description:
Jeremy is the National Practice Group Leader of Nexus Law Group’s Workplace & Safety legal practice.
Jeremy has 30 years of legal experience as a specialist workplace, employment and industrial relations lawyer with a focus on work health and safety and serious incident management and prosecutions by safety regulators
.
He is considered one of Australia’s leading and most experienced WHS lawyers.

He acts on behalf of corporations and government departments/government owned corporations (both State and Federal) and their officers and directors advising and managing serious workplace incidents, fatalities and prosecutions.

Jeremy is also a highly skilled advocate in employment and industrial relations jurisdictions. Providing commercial advice and outcomes to employers across the Eastern Australian States, Jeremy has acted and appeared in countless industrial disputes, unfair dismissals, general protections and award breach cases. 
He has also acted in the past as a prosecutor on behalf of the Workplace Ombudsman prosecuting breaches of the Fair Work Act and Awards.

Jeremy is an astute negotiator, strategist and advocate highly respected and regarded in this field. 

His clients include major national employers in the health, mining, manufacturing, infrastructure, maritime and electrical supply sectors. 

Jeremy is also author of the following text books and publications: 
• LexisNexis publication ‘WHS - What you need to know’ published 2012 
• Guide to WHS in New South Wales Mining
• Master Disaster, WHS guide to incident management, and 
• Guide on Workplace Bullying.

He is author and editor of WHS Lawyer blog and discussion group and a sought-after speaker and trainer on work health and safety issues. He is also a guest lecturer in WHS at various universities across Australia.
Jeremy has been acknowledged in 2018 by Doyles Legal Guide as a leading WHS lawyer nationally and as highly recommended in the areas of labour by Best Lawyers International Legal Guide.

general.headline: Associate Professor of Criminal Law & Evidence at Newcastle Law School
general.description:
Associate Professor Anderson practised exclusively in criminal law and reached the position of senior solicitor/advocate in the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions (NSW) before changing to an academic career. He completed his PhD in 2003 and his thesis involved an in-depth analysis of the natural life sentence for murder in New South Wales and the question of equal application of the law in sentencing. Associate Professor Anderson has published several articles and conferences papers arising from this and other research dealing with sentencing and related aspects of the criminal justice system. He has also published books on evidence law and criminal law and procedure with 2 new evidence books as works in progress and anticipated to be published in 2014. 

Associate Professor Anderson currently lectures in various courses taught by the Newcastle Law School, including Criminal Law and Procedure, Advanced Criminal Law,  and Evidence. Associate Professor Anderson has received eight teaching awards and citations recognising excellence in teaching at local, state and national levels. In 2010 he received the prestigious Australian Learning & Teaching Council's Teaching Excellence Award for Law, Economics, Business and Related Studies in the Australian Awards for University Teaching.

Sina has practiced as a specialist workplace relations lawyer since 2007, and has been a Law Society of NSW Accredited Specialist in Employment and Industrial Law since 2013.
 
He provides expert advice and assistance in a broad array of employment law and workplace relations matters, having exclusively practised in this area for many years, and in 2011 completed a Master of Laws specialising in the area.

Sina has more than a decade of experience providing legal advice, representation and assistance to employers, institutional clients and senior executives in a range of industry sectors, including FMCG, technology, energy, aviation, professional services, education, transport, construction, not-for-profit and government.

He is committed to assisting clients to find legally and commercially effective solutions to legal issues, and has experience in providing practical and timely advice and assistance in a wide range of contentious and non-contentious matters at Federal, State and local level.

Sina has presented at many firm and industry seminars and workshops to human resources professionals, executives and industry peers, and enjoys conveying complex legal issues in an engaging and informative manner.

Joe has specialised in employment related matters since 2001 and understands the financial and associated commercial pressures faced by employers when dealing with legal compliance, so a measured approach to the provision of legal services is often required with the minimisation of legal costs front of mind in all matters.

general.headline: Barrister at Hunter Street Chambers
general.description:
I have been practising at the New South Wales Bar since September 2012.

My main areas of practice are civil litigation, personal injury, commercial law, building disputes and administrative law. Further, I am experienced in mediation and alternative dispute resolution. 

I have appeared in the Royal Commission into Institutional Responses to Child Abuse (Case Studies 42 & 43) and prior to this was actively involved as Junior Counsel to Senior Counsel in the NSW Special Commission of Inquiry into matters relating to the Police investigation of certain child sexual abuse allegations in the Catholic Diocese of Maitland-Newcastle.

My practice extends from Newcastle and suburbs, Maitland and the Upper Hunter together with the mid and far North Coast (Port Macquarie, Kempsey, Taree, Coffs Harbour, Lismore, Grafton, and Ballina), Sydney and the Central Coast. 

I often appear in the Local Court, District Court & Supreme Courts of New South Wales as well as the Federal Court of Australia. I appear regularly in the New South Wales Workers Compensation Commission.

I have a keen interest in the recently established NSW Civil & Administrative Tribunal (NCAT) which began its operation in January 2014 and have prepared and presented papers which address such matters as its structure, jurisdiction and operation, the appeals process and costs. Should you like a copy of any of these papers please do not hesitate to email, contact my Clerk Leoni Freeman on (02) 4032451 or follow the links below:

http://www.hunterstreetchambers.com.au/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/NCAT_McMahon.pdf

http://www.hunterstreetchambers.com.au/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/NCAT-Appeals-Simon-J-McMahon-February-2014.pdf

general.headline: Solicitor at Premier Compensation Lawyers
general.description:
Elyse Bonnici is a solicitor at Premier Compensation Lawyers.

Elyse is admitted as a solicitor in the Supreme Court of NSW and the High Court of Australia. She obtained a Bachelor of Arts from the University of Western Sydney and a Bachelor of Laws from Macquarie University.

Elyse practices predominately in Personal Injury Litigation, including Workers Compensation, Work Injury Damages, Motor Vehicle Accidents, Public Liability, Medical Negligence and Claims on Superannuation. She also has experience in Property Transactions, Wills and Probate and has litigated in various Courts around Australia.

Elyse enjoys the challenge of finding practical and cost effective solutions to complex legal issues. 

Elyse acts for clients with vast ranges of injuries including brain injuries, spinal injuries, orthopaedic injuries and psychological injuries. She has experience working with a variety of injured people and has acted on behalf of many people from different backgrounds and of different ages, including children, who have suffered injury and loss.

Over her years of practice, Elyse has acquired an in depth knowledge of legislation governing Personal Injury Litigation, including the complicated and ever changing Workers Compensation Legislation.

Elyse is approachable and friendly and enjoys utilizing her knowledge to assist every day injured people overcome difficult legal situations and achieve excellent results. She prides herself on ensuring her clients receive a jargon free, personalized service and feel informed, included and respected in a flexible and friendly environment.

Elyse truly understands the devastating difficulties associated with suffering a life changing injury and provides her clients with support, every step of the way.

Elyse is community focused and is an active member of the Maltese Community Council of New South Wales.

At Joplin Lawyers, knowledge is power for our legal team and our clients.

As the firm’s director, my role is representing our Family Law clients. 
I hold a Bachelor of Laws from James Cook University Cairns and was admitted as a Solicitor of the Supreme Court of New South Wales and the High Court of Australia in 2007.

I am also on the Independent Children’s Lawyer (ICL) panel with the Legal Aid Commission of New South Wales and have conducted Family Law matters throughout Australia.

I am a vocal and dynamic advocate for increasing the awareness of the prevalence of domestic violence in the community. A vigorous believer in the necessity of rehabilitation processes for the perpetrators of domestic violence. I believe that if we do not engage in constructing a meaningful dialogue with perpetrators by way of facilitating programs through the Criminal Law Justice system there is no way to protect the victims of domestic violence.

I pride myself on offering astute legal representation and an emphasis on warm personal attention. I view my clients as partners and focus on building long-term relationships with them. I am committed to offering responsive services and obtaining satisfactory completions to client’s legal matters.

jobs.description:
The Brisbane based Prisoners Legal Service (PLS) is Australia’s oldest independent legal service for prisoners and their families.

I lead a small team dedicated to providing high quality legal advice and assistance and to be involved in innovative legal service delivery programs, working in partnership with other community organisations, the private legal profession and government to advance the conditions and human rights of people who are incarcerated in Queensland.

The Director/Principal Solicitor is responsible for the overall management and day to day operation of the PLS ensuring that the mission and operational plan are implemented. I am also responsible for the supervision of legal practice within the organisation.

The position of Public Interest Monitor was established in Queensland under the Crime and Misconduct Act 2001 (Qld), and the Police Powers and Responsibilities Act 2000 (Qld). Under the Crime and Misconduct Act, the PIM monitors applications for, and the use of, surveillance warrants and covert search warrants. The PIM also monitors applications for the interception of telecommunications services by the QPS and CCC.

Under the Police Powers and Responsibilities Act, the PIM monitors applications for, and the use of, surveillance device warrants, retrieval warrants and covert search warrants.

The PIM’s primary role is to represent the public interest where law enforcement agencies seek approval to use search powers and surveillance devices that have the capacity to infringe the rights and civil liberties of citizens. The role is based on the public interest in ensuring that law enforcement agencies meet all legislative requirements, and that their proposed actions do not extend beyond the parameters laid down by the Queensland Parliament.

John is the Chairman of 9th Floor Windeyer Chambers. 

He was a member of the NSW Police force before being called to the Bar. He practiced in Crime for a number of years, but thereafter has practised in civil jurisdictions including the High Court, Supreme Court, District Court and various tribunals. John has run many high profile cases including the first significant class action to come to hearing being the Helix Case; Pareezer v Coca Cola (shooting of vendor machine filler). Since then he continues to specialise in class actions and personal injury matters.

John has appeared in various State and Federal Courts in Victoria, Western Australia and Queensland.

John has previously sat as a committee member of the Australian Lawyers Alliance and Chairman of the Lobbying Sub Committee. He is active in promoting review of the Civil Liability, Motor Accident Compensation, Workers Injury Management and Legal Profession Acts within the state legislature.

jobs.description:
Ronald Frigo graduated in law with honours. In 1998 he was admitted as a barrister of the Supreme Court of Queensland. Over the period 1998 to January 2018, almost 20 years, he has practised at the Queensland private bar appearing in all courts and tribunals, including trial and appellate jurisdictions which sit in Queensland
He specialises in litigation, across the commercial, civil and criminal jurisdictions, within his areas of practice, and has built a well established mediation practice both as counsel and mediator. He regularly advises and appears for and against Commonwealth, State and Local Governments and their various instrumentalities. He has acted as the barrister for litigants in high profile cases, including cases of special interest and public importance.
He now enjoys a broad legal practice which includes work in Brisbane and regional areas, including the Gold Coast and Northern New South Wales. He has been the preferred counsel for several national top tier law firms in Brisbane. He has worked with and against some of the most prominent and respected legal minds in this State, including pre-eminent Queens Counsel and now serving judges of the Court of Appeal, Supreme Court and Federal Court.
An illustration of Ron’s recent cases in both the civil and criminal courts has seen him regularly appear or been involved in acting for or against the following litigants:
•	Local, State and Federal Governments
•	Major Banks & Financial Institutions
•	Public Listed ASX Companies
•	ASIC, ACCC, Office of Fair Trading (Qld), Crime & Corruption Commission (Qld)
•	Professional negligence cases involving top tier accounting, law firms and financial/insurance advisors

general.headline: Chief Executive Officer at SHS LAW
general.description:
SHS LAW (formerly Foott LAW & Co) is one of Australia’s oldest legal firm (Est. 1868) and is an amalgamation of several old and established legal firms which have come together under the same banner. Increasingly the firm’s clientele is drawn from persons and organizations resident from outside Australia as more and more of the firm’s clients are engaged in cross-border trade and commerce.

Foott LAW & Co is boutique legal firm which originated in the regional City of Grafton in NSW in 1868 at a time when a great majority of Australia’s wealth and population was based in rural areas. The firm continues to operate in the same stately premises where it first commenced. The Clarence Valley on the North Coast of NSW was and remains one of Australia’s most fertile and densely populated rural regions and the country retreat for many of Australia’s oldest and most wealthy families.

SHS LAW is a premium player in the Australasian legal market. Focusing on market sectors that are dynamic and evolving, SHS Law advises individuals and companies on transactions that impact and shape world markets.

With over 300 Solicitors and professionals, our strong legal team is acknowledged throughout Australasia as leaders in many of our five core service areas: Migration Law, Commercial Law, Family Law, Property Law and Civil Law. Our lawyers maintain a ruthless sense of relevance in digesting information, data and people. We have a no nonsense common sense approach to law, legal principles and its application in day to day life.

Our clients range from families and small businesses through to government agencies, private equity and multinational corporations.

general.headline: FORENSIC ACCOUNTANT - CERTIFIED FRAUD EXAMINER
general.description:
BIOGRAPHY

Chris Taylor has over 20 years commercial accounting experience within various organisations providing him with core competencies in the areas of; financial and management accounting, business valuations, business reconstruction, insolvency and fraud risk. Following his Bachelor of Economics degree in 1998 Chris earned his Master of Accountancy from the University of New England in 2000. In 2012 Chris was admitted to the degree of Master of Forensic Accounting from the University of Wollongong.

During the past seven years Chris has been an advocate in establishing fraud and internal controls as an integral component in managing the risk of fraud within the hospitality industry. Known as a forensic thinker, Chris has provided hotel/resort owners, managers and employees with expert counsel in the fields of forensic accounting and fraud risk management. Through a combination of expertise in accounting and economics he is also qualified to quantify economic damages.

Chris has acted on behalf of creditors in insolvency proceedings as Accountant and financial advisor; restructured businesses and debt to accommodate changed business circumstances; negotiated purchase and sale of businesses, and overhauled business processes to favourably impact clients' bottom line. Chris has conducted financial and corporate compliance investigations involving construction companies, building contractors, restaurants and hotels.

Chris is a member of the Association of Certified Fraud Examiners, Fellow of the Institute of Public
Accountants and holds an Accounting Public Practice Certificate.

jobs.description:
TAYLORHAY Business and Forensic Accountants was founded by Chris Taylor in 2013 to provide expert Forensic Accounting knowledge and advice to individuals, small-businesses, law firms, financial service providers and corporations.

As the principal of the firm Chris specialises in Fraud Investigations and is responsible for the management and delivery of both proactive and reactive investigation services including;

Fraud Investigations, Fraud Risk Assessments, Fraud Prevention & Deterrence,	Forensic Accounting, Expert Reports and Litigation Support.

AREAS OF COMPETENCY INCLUDE:

Financial Statement Fraud, Asset Misappropriation, Procurement Fraud, Payroll Fraud, Commercial Bribery, Economic Loss Assessments, Interviewing Techniques and Data Analysis.

Duties included interviewing suspects, gathering evidence that is suitable to a Court and preparing concise forensic reports involving criminal and disciplinary investigations.

The ACFE is the world's largest anti-fraud organization and premier provider of anti-fraud training and education. Together with nearly 75,000 members, the ACFE is reducing business fraud worldwide and inspiring public confidence in the integrity and objectivity within the profession.

Our Sydney Chapter has over 200 members and we meet regularly to bring new and emerging ideas and themes around fraud and financial crime, to our membership base. The Chapter draws its membership across a broad spectrum and is comprised of in-house fraud practitioners and senior managers, law enforcement officers, academics, regulators, consultants and sole practitioners.

As a member of the Executive Committee my duties and responsibilities included;

•	Assume the functions and responsibilities of the General Manager as required.
•	Contribute to collective Resort Policy decision making process.
•	Make recommendations for improvement and management of the Resort’s physical structures and service from a financial perspective.
•	Ensure all Departments of the Resort are managed from a financial aspect and maintaining service standards through sound financial practices.
•	Implement & maintain internal systems to ensure the provision of effective control of assets, revenues, and disbursements.
•	Identify, analyse and prepare financial models for internal and external business opportunities that will maximize the ability of the business to achieve the objectives of sustainable future profit and cash flow growth.
•	Validate the integrity of the payables, receivables, payroll activities ensuring that all routines and reporting procedures are completed accurately and in a timely manner. 
•	Provide effective and efficient day-to-day control, administration, information and reporting systems
•	Interpret financial results and work with respective heads of departments to maximise Operating results and providing them with the information and tools for future planning and control.
•	Maintain accurate records of all assets, liabilities, and business related transactions of the Company.
•	Conduct internal audits on a regular and scheduled basis.
•	Develop a program of further financial development for Department Heads and Managers in relation to their awareness of the financial management of their respective departments.

The Pearl South Pacific Resort, Spa & Championship Golf course is a 78 room 4.5 star
resort located in Pacific Harbour, Fiji. The following duties and responsibilities were a
requirement of this position.

•	Acting General Manager between Jan 08 – Feb 08.
•	Management of finance team.
•	Ultimate responsibility of all finance functions of the hotel.
•	Implement Hotel Accounting Policies & Procedures.
•	Supervise all operations in Accounts, Purchasing, Cost Control and Payroll departments.
•	Review, implement and maintain all systems of internal control.
•	Preparation of daily, weekly, monthly, six monthly and annual financial reports.
•	Prepare yearly operating and capital budgets.
•	Implement cost controls for a $3m capital expenditure program.
•	Maintenance and audit of the hotels Property Management System (PMS) Fidelio.
•	Assisting heads of department to manage their budgets.
•	Preparation and presentation of financial statements as required under Fiji
•	Company legislation and international generally accepted accounting standards.

The principal companies of the group are;

1. The Rarotongan Beach Resort& Spa; a 157 room, four star, full service resort; and
2. The Aitutaki Lagoon Resort & Spa; a 36 bungalow, four star, full service resort; and
3. Oceania Insurance limited; a captive insurance company; and
4. Various hotel development sites throughout the Cook Islands.

As a senior officer of the company I contributed to improvements in all facets of the business. From time to time I was the senior executive on island and performed the role of Acting General Manager.

Employed on a contractual basis to provide expert accounting and financial management to companies placed in voluntary administration. Contracts included 5 Thai restaurants owned by ThainaBox Noodle Bar Pty Ltd and 43 carwash sites and 31 franchised sites operated by Carlovers Carwash Limited.

Duties & Responsibilities

•	Assess the intrinsic worth to creditors for the continued operation of the business.
•	Prepare operating budgets for review and approval by the voluntary Administrator.
•	Prepare and submit to creditors a “Report as to Affairs”, of the company.
•	Investigate and report possible breaches of the Corporation Act and offences.
•	Assess the intrinsic worth to creditors for the continued operation of the business.
•	Prepare operating budgets for review and approval by the voluntary Administrator.
•	Detailed analysis of transactions and events in the context of asset fraud, 
mismanagement and financial statement manipulation.

A long favorite quote, from a well known 900 year old.

general.headline: Solicitor at Teece Hodgson & Ward
general.description:
I hold a Bachelor of Laws, a Bachelor of Arts (majoring in Sociology) and a Master of Applied Law (Wills & Estates).

I commenced my legal career in 2006, working as a paralegal in a general practice while completing my studies, prior to being admitted as a solicitor in 2008.  

Following admission, I practised, for 7 years, as a general practitioner in regional New South Wales where I practised in criminal law, family law, property law, civil litigation, commercial law and wills and estates (including estate litigation). 

In June 2015 I moved to a renowned Newcastle law firm to practise exclusively in Estate Litigation. 

During my time in Newcastle I primarily acted for Plaintiffs in family provision claims in New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland. I have successfully represented numerous claimants in settlements and proceedings.

I joined Teece Hodgson and Ward Solicitors in May 2017 and I work in their Estate Litigation team where I act for both Plaintiffs and Estates in all aspects of estate litigation, including testamentary capacity, family provision claims, and administration suits.

I have considerable Court experience; having run hearings in the Local Court, District Court, Supreme Court, Family Court and Federal Circuit Court.

general.headline: Senior Solicitor at Mullane & Lindsay
general.description:
I have a real passion for family law practice - I believe that family law clients are often experiencing the worst time of their lives: they may be leaving the family home, no longer with their children, or facing financial insecurity and assisting in the establishment of a new legal framework is an extremely gratifying experience.

I was admitted to practice in 2006 and have worked in family law since that time.
I have vast experience in dealing with the issues surrounding divorce, disputes arising from breakdown of de facto relationships, the complexities of property division including where partnerships, trusts or businesses are involved, and matters involving children including child abuse, domestic violence, relocation, recovery of children and child support. I also have extensive experience in the preparation of Financial Agreements and Consent Orders as well as the representation of clients in negotiations, mediations and at Court.

I have completed a Masters in Applied Family Law. And I am a member of the Hunter Valley Family Law Practitioners Association.

Since graduation I have volunteered at the “drop-in” legal advice nights at the University of Newcastle Legal Centre - advising clients in relation to family law matters. 

I am the editor of The Family Lawyer (http://lawyerfamily.blogspot.com.au/) - a blog dedicated to discussing matters of interest in family law.

general.headline: COO, Nexus Law Group.  Building the future of Law.
general.description:
As COO, I oversight an incredible team that supports the Lawyers who are part of Nexus Law Group - a dynamic firm operating in the NewLaw space. 

Our business model was built on the belief that we could provide a better practice option to lawyers and in doing so, service clients more effectively.

Lawyers in Nexus Law Group enjoy the benefits, flexibility and autonomy of independent practice, with the advantages of working under a recognised brand and national structure that promotes collaborative work and referrals within the team.  This means they can build their own practices and give personal direct service to their clients, while drawing on the complimentary expertise and group support systems of the firm.

I started my career as a lawyer at Blake Dawson Waldron (now Ashurst) in Sydney and after several years in practice, relocated internationally and moved into legal recruitment.  I spent 14 years living and working in Asia, Europe and Australia where I helped lawyers structure their career and realise their professional and personal aspirations. These experiences with lawyers attracted me to Nexus as I saw that there was a need for something beyond the offerings of traditional practice.

Our hard work in practice innovation has been recognised through a number of significant industry awards including the Legal Innovation Index, Boutique Law Firm of the Year (twice), Westpac’s Business’ of Tomorrow and finalist for Law Firm of the Year in 2017 and Telstra Business Awards.  

My ultimate goal is to play a positive part in the development and innovation of the legal profession.  In doing so, on a daily basis I work to look after our lawyers, provide the skills and support they need to develop successful practices and to create an environment in which they can flourish and have long, satisfying and well-balanced careers.

If you would like to know more about the way we work, please don't hesitate to get in touch (jak@nexuslawyers.com.au or +612 9016 0141).

jobs.description:
The Women Lawyers Association of NSW is the peak body representing women lawyers in NSW. Established in 1952, today the Association serves a community of over 9000 members across the state.  Our commitment to transforming the experience of women in law is achieved through proactive law reform, strategic alliances, change initiatives and thought leadership and our input is regularly sought by legislative and government bodies. In 2014, the Association launched the Women Lawyers Network, which empowers women lawyers to create the career they want through a series of workshops, mentoring initiatives, innovative resources and connections. 

We are also proud to have relaunched the Newcastle Chapter in 2014 and are very excited to be running a number of great events for the benefit of local lawyers in this vibrant regional legal community.

general.headline: Accredited Specialist (Children's Law) & Principal Lawyer
general.school: Romeo High School, Romeo Michigan US
general.description:
I am the Principle solicitor of Harpers Legal of Waratah.

After completing my University degree at the University of New England in Armidale, I commenced practice in Moree in North West NSW. This regional centre allowed me to practice in a diverse range of areas of law including Criminal law, Family Law, Litigation and large international commercial transactional work and litigation. The people of Moree were welcoming to me and my family and with my husband we grew to a family of four. Country practice was a fantastic experience.

After five years of remote regional practice, we chose as a family we moved to Taree for a year then onto Newcastle, finally settling in Waratah. I initially worked with Turnbull Hill Lawyers in Charlestown, but after the addition of our third child who completes our family, and a subsequent period of maternity leave, I opened my practice as a sole practitioner.

I love the freedom of my practice and the juxtaposition of the sense of responsibility that being a small business owner creates.

general.headline: Partner at Marsdens Law Group
general.description:
The Basics:

I am currently a Partner in our Local Government, Planning and Environmental Law Department.

I have been with Marsdens since 1986 and have a broad range of experience in a number of areas of Litigation and have been a part of the Environmental Law section since 2001.

My clients are mainly Local Government Authorities and as well as providing advice on planning and Local Government matters, I also appear in the Land and Environment Court and Local Court.

The Marsdens Law Group History:

Marsdens Law Group was founded by John Marsden as a one man practice in 1968. Since he started the firm, John set high standards of service, professionalism and commitment. It was these standards and John's voracious appetite for work and innovation that saw the firm expand, at times rapidly, to become one of the largest firms in the State.

In that time the practice has grown from a one man, one secretary operation to a firm with almost 150 staff and 4 offices located throughout the Sydney Metropolitan Area. 
The firm has been successful because it understands that Our Clients Come First. 

Marsdens are not simply your average law firm. We provide our clients "Service with a Difference".

Marsdens offer many other services which include:

Commercial Law

Commercial Litigation Law

Compensation Law

Criminal Law

Estate Planning

Family Law

Local Government & Environmental Law

Property Law

www.marsdens.net.au

Contact David on: dbaird@marsdens.net.au

general.headline: Partner at Boskovitz Lawyers

jobs.description:
During my time at Ashurst, I worked on some notable PPPs and infrastructure projects including Westconnex, Sydney Metro, Moscow-Kazan High Speed Rail PPP, Social and Affordable Housing Fund and various wind farm construction projects.

I resigned in January 2018 whilst on maternity leave.

In 2013, Brookfield Asset Management and the Johnson Controls Group (a Fortune 500 company listed on the NYSE) created a joint venture vehicle called "Brookfield Johnson Controls". 

Throughout my time at Brookfield Johnson Controls, I assisted the business with its complex infrastructure transactions, including the Perth Stadium PPP, ACT Courts, University of Canberra Public Hospital, the Defence CMS bid and the NSW Police Property Portfolio bid.  I also provided advice about work performed in critical environments, including in data and telecommunication centres. 

In 2015, Brookfield and Johnson Controls effected a de-merger of the worldwide Brookfield Johnson Controls business units and I then moved with Brookfield to its new business Brookfield Global Integrated Solutions or BGIS.

Kate assisted the business with its complex infrastructure projects, PPPs and BOOT
      schemes. Her areas of specialty included O&M, Project Management and Construction
      Management contracts. She was also heavily involved in the Brookfield Johnson
      
      Controls joint venture.

During her time at Gadens, Kate developed an expertise in a wide range of property acquisitions and disposals, including acting for Property Funds and Developers looking to invest in Shopping Centres, Licensed Premises (Pubs and Hotels) and residential development sites. Kate also advised Landlords and Tenants with their commercial, industrial and retail leasing.

general.headline: Partner | Corporate | Head of Infrastructure, Mining and Commodities | APC (Board) member | Norton Rose Fulbright AU
general.description:
Corporate lawyer based in Brisbane, Australia, specialising in:

Mergers and acquisitions (M&A)
Mining and resources, including operational work for the coal, gas and mineral sectors
Infrastructure, including access to rail and port
Joint ventures

I have over 20 years’ experience advising in the energy and resources sectors and am head of Norton Rose Fulbright's Infrastructure, Mining and Commodities team in Australia.

I advise energy and resources clients on strategic issues and operational requirements, including: 
(1) multi-jurisdictional and multi-asset M&A, joint venture arrangements, organisational restructuring and asset sales; 
(2) contract drafting and negotiation, including coal offtake agreements and strategic supply agreements; and 
(3) rail and port infrastructure access and pricing, including haulage agreements and access to coal export terminals.

Recent work includes assisting with buying / selling interests in operating coal mines, port and rail capacity transfers, advising on Aurizon Network's rail access undertaking, establishing joint venture arrangements (both incorporated and unincorporated) and negotiating rail haulage and port services agreements.

I am an active contributor to the resources and energy sectors through my involvement with AMPLA (the Australian Energy and Resources Lawyers Association), where I have been an active member for more than 18 years.

Partner at HWL Ebsworth
general.description:
Karen has a results-oriented, practical approach to resolving legal issues for financial market participants. She has over 20 years experience in banking law and regulation and 9 years experience in investment and commercial banking including a rich knowledge of the Personal Property Securities Act gained from an 18 month role as legal counsel to Westpac's PPS Reform Program and providing advice to clients on PPSA issues at HWL Ebsworth.  Acts on domestic and international finance transactions, the restructuring of corporate groups experiencing financial difficulties, distressed debt transactions. Advises financial institutions on Australian regulatory issues.

Specialties: PPSA. Asset-based financing. Banking regulation. Corporate finance and syndicated lending transactions. Debt capital markets. Derivatives documentation. Financial markets clearing and settlement. Infrastructure and project financing. Securitisation. Restructuring and workouts.

jobs.description:
Assisting clients to establish or consider the appropriateness of their Personal Property Securities Act (PPSA) strategy, including updating template documents (such as credit applications, supply terms and hire and lease agreements) for the PPSA, the provision of PPSA registration manuals and training staff to make effective PPSA registrations.
Advising on actual and potential priority disputes between competing PPSA security interests and /or other security interests, and the enforecement of PPSA security interests.
Assistance with Personal Property Securities Register (PPSR) matters such as interpreting PPSR search results, arranging for the establishment of secured party groups, identifying ineffective PPSR registrations, making effective PPSR registrations, undertaking "find and claim" in respect of migrated security interests, challenging and having PPSR registrations corrected or ended through administrative and judicial processes, full and partial releases of collateral.
Acting for lenders, borrowers, agents, arrangers and other participants in connection with the establishment, amendment and restructure of debt facilities.

jobs.jobTitle: Legal Counsel, Personal Property Securities Reform Progam
jobs.description: One of two legal counsel working in a team of 60 professionals on the implementation of reforms necessary as a result of the commencement of the Personal Property Securities Act 2009 (Cth).  Provide general assistance in relation to the legal aspects of the bank's Personal Property Securities Reform program, and specifically in relation to the reforms as they affect Westpac Institutional Bank (WIB). Plan the documentation amendment program for WIB, review and amend some of the bank's documents, liaise with external counsel in regard to the preparation of new security documents and the amendment of others. Attend and present seminars and workshops on the new legislation. Provide formal and ad hoc legal advice about the new legislation and its impact on them for the WIB business units and the Program team. Prepare instructions to external counsel to advise on some PPSR issues, and liaise with them (and relevant legal personnel within the bank) in relation to that advice. Represent the bank at meetings of various industry groups, including PPSR Legal Special Interest Group and PPSR Business Process Special Interest Group.

Lead small teams on transactional work including US$50M secured facility for private bus fleet operator ComfortDelGro Cabcharge, restructuring facilities provided by Westpac to a group of companies experiencing financial difficulties, loan facilites by St.George to self managed superannuation funds, trade finance facilities by Rabobank to the government of Sri Lanka supported by an EFIC guarantee and by ABN AMRO to DuPont.
3 month secondment to the Product & Distribution team, Counsel & Secretariat at Westpac - product development work and solving legal issues for business partners across the bank.
Provided legal advice to members of the business units of Westpac Institutional Bank.

Advised an ASX listed company with operations in Europe, USA, Asia and Australia in connection with the restructure of its corporate group. 
Acted for the senior financier in connection with intercreditor and security trust arrangments relating to its project financing facilities, including advice following the borrower's default under its subordinated bonds. 
Drafted, negotiated and settled a US$258 million syndicated facility agreement and related Dutch, Indonesian and Singaporean security documentation for an international mining company to facilitate refinancing by its joint venturer in an Indonesian gold and copper mine of obligations under US bonds. Also advised on a US$427 million bilateral loan agreement and related security documentation for the vendor financing of the sale of a 7% interest in the project entity to the local joint venturer in compliance with Indonesian government requirements.
Lead teams of up to 15 lawyers. 
Member of Women@Freehills Liasion Group.
Clients included ERG, Bayerische Hypo- und Vereinsbank AG, Singapore Branch, Newmont Mining and Caledonia Investments.

Acted for a variety of foreign and domestic financial institutions to draft, negotiate and settle documentation for the establishment of senior, mezzanine, bilateral and syndicated debt facilities for property developers, REITs, mining companies, gas retailers, fund managers and other corporations.  
Advised a foreign bank on the establishment of its Australian subsidiary, the obtaining of that entity’s authority to carry on business as an ADI, an offshore banking unit authorisation, an Australian financial services licence and the transfer of assets and liabilities from the Sydney Branch of the Bank to the new subsidiary under relevant legislation. Also assisted the Bank to revise its standard trade finance documentation.
Acting for potential buyer of an infrastructure asset from receivers and managers.
Negotiated a facility for a bank to sell non-performing auto loans to a debt recovery company. 
Acted for the originator of medical practitioner loan and lease receivables on a $250 million wholesale warehouse securitisation of them. 
Acted on the establishment of a $230 million commercial mortgage backed commercial paper program for a REIT.
Assisted Australian fund manager to establish master and satellite funds in the Cayman islands to invest in credit sensitive assets and offer securities denominated in JPY, USD and AUD.
Introduced new clients to the firm and played a leading role in business development activities for them.
Member of group which redefined and developed the role of Special Counsel at the firm.
Instrumental in establishing a professional development program at the firm for lawyers 0-3 years post qualification experience.
Edited several editions of the firm's Banking & Finance Newsletter.
Prepared and settled the firm’s precedent syndicated loan facility agreement.
Clients included Absolute Capital, Bank of China, Experien, ING, National Australia Bank, Sydney Airport Corporation, St.George Bank, Westpac.

Responsible for all transactions handled by the firm which involved finance or financial services. This involved reviewing or drafting and negotiating the transaction documentation, attending settlement, providing post-signing services and supervising junior lawyers working on such transactions.
Transactions included a $450 million reset convertible note issue by Macquarie Bank to the Ontario Teacher’s Pension Plan Board in connection with Sydney’s M7 motorway, the funding for Westfield’s successful $1.9 billion bid for AMP Shopping Centre Trust, a $140 million project financing of the Oakey Power station, rescheduling $820 million debt facilities for NextGen Networks, a cross border lease of “Farscape”, a cable television series, a tender for the purchase of a major Australian wholesale currency services business, the establishment of an ATM joint venture, advising and assisting administrators in connection with the administration of an Australian business, advising on the Australian law aspects of transactions involving a US company with worldwide operations in Chapter 11 bankruptcy.
Established a core finance precedent document database for the firm.

Represented borrowers, providers and arrangers of debt finance and Australian and foreign issuers of debt securities. Involved in lending and leasing transactions, the securitisation of rental income streams and in project finance and debt capital markets work. Drafted and negotiated documentation for structured finance transactions involving complex intercreditor arrangements.
Transactions included the underwritten issuance of a variety of debt instruments (CPI indexed bonds, subordinated notes, transferrable certificates of deposit, convertible notes, credit wrapped notes, floating and fixed rate securities) and the establishment of Australian, Euro market and American debt securities issuance programs for foreign and Australian issuers. Responsible for reviewing or drafting and negotiating documentation, providing legal opinions, attending settlement, providing post-signing services, supervision of junior lawyers.
Advised Austraclear on the establishment of Eurobond entitlements trading within the Austraclear system. 
Drafted debt capital markets precedent documents.
Seconded for 7 months to Bankers Trust Australia in 1997 as legal counsel, company secretariat. Negotiated and settled documentation for the Bank’s new Adelaide premises, made a submission for the Bank to the Reserve Bank of Australia on netting and a further one on the capital adequacy treatment of a collateralised derivative product, prepared standard documentation for RITS and CHESS payment facilities offered by the Bank.
Seconded for 2 months to Advance Bank in 1996 as legal counsel, treasury and business banking. Responsible for a number of projects including negotiating the documentation for the Bank’s US$150 million subordinated euro note issuance and the establishment of its domestic transferable note issuance program.
Appointed as Senior Associate in 1995.
Edited Banking Law Update, a monthly firm publication, during 1994.
Part time work while undertaking law degree.

general.headline: Environmental and energy lawyer at Baker McKenzie (Special Counsel)
general.description: Specialties: Commonwealth and State environmental law (Australia); climate change law and policy; renewable energy law and policy; major project facilitation mechanisms in Queensland; waste and reuse law; planning law; land contamination law; contract negotiation.

jobs.description:
The Queensland Climate Advisory Council’s (QCAC) purpose is to provide the Queensland Government with expert advice on opportunities and directions to maximise the economic and social potential of the transition to a zero net emission and climate resilient economy.

The 15 members are eminent business, industry and research leaders who will act as a conduit between the Queensland Government and the private sector to identify priorities for climate change action and innovation.

The QCAC’s first role will be to apply its expertise to enhance the delivery of the Queensland climate transition and adaptation strategies. Following this, the QCAC will participate in the 2019 review of climate transition actions and will identify future policy actions for Queensland Government consideration.

jobs.jobTitle: Special Counsel, Major Projects - Environmental Markets
jobs.description:
My recent work in the climate change law and policy area has included advising the Queensland Government on strategy and structuring for its $500m Land Restoration Fund. I also advise on the development of Emissions Reduction Fund projects, emissions reduction market analysis for global companies, emission reduction purchase agreements, ERF Safeguard Mechanism implications and corporate reporting requirements under the National Greenhouse and Energy Reporting Act 2007 (NGER scheme). 

I have also recently been advising on planning and environment risk issues for several new renewable energy projects in Queensland.

I am listed in Best Lawyers for Planning and Environment and Climate Change Law and in 2017, I was honoured to be invited to sit on the Queensland Environment Minister's Queensland Climate Advisory Council. 

I advise clients on project approval strategies, environmental enforcement and compliance (state and Commonwealth), contaminated land, planning law, cultural heritage, and water law matters for new developments and expansions of existing infrastructure.

I also advise on environmental compliance issues for existing and new operations, particularly in relation to initial responses to environmental regulators in the event of enforcement action.

I have a strong interest in the development of new law and policy and was invited to participate in the State government's working group for the development of a statutory guideline to support the Environmental Protection (Chain of Responsibility) Amendment Act 2016 amendments to Queensland's environmental law.

general.headline: Director - Sydney Story Factory Parramatta
general.description: With years of experience in community engagement and development, performing arts and business, I feel most fulfilled when using this cross-disciplinary knowledge to build cohesive teams and communities, in order to improve people’s life outcomes. In particular, I believe in the power of art and creativity to achieve personal and social development. I also have a keen interest in contemporary social change methodologies, such as co-design, collective impact, transmedia storytelling, systemic leadership and movement making. My motto is: “fun is serious business.”

jobs.description:
The Sydney Story Factory is a not-for-profit creative writing centre for young people. Our priority is marginalised young people - those most at risk of losing confidence in their writing and switching off at school. We light the spark of creativity and help them find their voice. 

My job entails setting up and running the second creative writing centre for young people, Sydney Story Factory Parramatta. The new centre will run creative writing and storytelling programs for young people aged 7 to 17 from across Greater Western Sydney.

Hope+ is our collective journey towards better outcomes for young people in Fairfield LGA with an emphasis on employment, education, refugee settlement, mental health and overall wellbeing. We strive towards systemic change and social innovation, which will improve the experience of growing up in Fairfield and transitioning into meaningful work and adulthood. Our journey is guided by social change methodologies called collective impact and co-design but we are always on the lookout for other creative and evidence-based tools that we could add to our social impact basket of goodies.

My tasks (mostly through collaboration with others) include:
- Community engagement
- Cross-sector engagement
- Convening networks
- Group facilitation
- System leadership
- Research
- Co-design
- Service mapping

- Capacity building
- Online engagement

- Running a WordPress website
- Setting up an evaluation system

- Having fun

Villawood is one of the most disadvantaged urban neighborhoods in NSW.
      

    In my job I engaged the local community to identify challenges, offer support and
      where possible co-design solutions.
      

    
      

... See more

Srbi za Srbe (http://srbizasrbe.net/) is a highly innovative international humanitarian organisations that connects Serbian refugees and economic migrants who've settled in economically prosperous Western countries, with disadvantaged Serbian families with four or more children, still living in the region of Former Yugoslavia. Often, these families live in unsafe environments where they face daily hostility form their neighbours. This creates barriers to normal life, such as inability to travel to work, school, play and so on.

I worked with a creative Belgrade core team to come up with solutions that will better connect donors with those in need of support. We would work with the families to find a way for them to live sustainably from their own labour. This was often done through small businesses or farming in rural areas. 

My tasks (mostly through collaboration with others) included:

- Visiting disadvantaged families in war-torn parts of Kosovo and other parts of the region, to identify their needs.
- Producing video and photographic content in order to develop fundraising campaigns.
- Purchasing required goods and organising delivery
- Developing a supportive network for the families
- Organising community development and sporting activities to build community cohesion and harmony
- Enjoying every single interaction with amasing people who have hope after everything they've been through

As a freelancer, I directed a number of theatre and media productions.

Between March 2010 and May 2011, I facilitated workshops in directing, film-making and cinema history to NIDA's postgraduate students. I also performed many administrative and finance tasks for the postgraduate department, such as payroll, Accounts Payable, filing and updating databases.

jobs.companyName: Shell Innovation Challenge 2014 by The Australian Newspaper
jobs.jobTitle: Winner, Minerals & Energy Category, Shell Innovation Challenge
jobs.description:
A NEW method to process ores of nickel promises to boost production of the metal, which is used in stainless steel, amid a looming worldwide nickel shortage.

The method, developed by Julian Malnic, of Sydney’s Direct Nickel, and colleagues, is expected to increase the exploitation of laterite rocks containing the element. Laterite rocks, which are formed through weathering, bear most of the world’s future nickel resources but they are expensive to process with conventional technology, Malnic says.

Most nickel is obtained from other kinds of deposits but these resources are fast being depleted or are too deep to mine, he says. “Nickel is forecast to suffer a supply shortfall from 2017.”

Malnic and his team have made the ­finals of The Australian Innovation Challengeawards with the technology. The awards are run by The Australian in association with Shell with the support of the federal Department of Industry. http://www.theaustralian.com.au/innovationchallenge

Fluid Minerals is pioneering the in situ leaching of the main sulphide metal minerals
      including the main copper minerals. The Company is currently in the process of
      generating its first Information Memorandum and assembling a management team.
      

    
      Regards Julian Malnic

http://www.sydneyminingclub.org
